Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Constraining Mechanisms of Tropical Climate Change Using Simulations and Proxies of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Last Glacial Maximum (LGM), that period of time 21,000 years ago when the earth was glaciated and significantly colder than today, provides a unique set of boundary conditions to test climate general circulation models. This proposal aims to use simulations of the LGM to determine if the Walker Circulation, a coupled atmosphere-ocean system in the tropical Pacific, was stronger or weaker at that time. The project will attempt to address several important questions including:

1) How important are changes in the hydrological cycle, sea surface temperature gradients, and exposure of the Sunda shelf in affecting past intensity of the Walker Circulation?
2) What is the impact of model bias in the interaction among these mechanisms?
3) Can the different reconstructions of past climate in the tropical Pacific be reconciled and used to constrain each of these mechanisms?
4) How well do state-of-the-art climate models simulate the response of the Walker circulation to the exposure of the Sunda shelf due to lower sea level during the LGM.

The models to be used in the study were also used to produce key paleoclimate simulations that will be discussed in the IPCC AR5 reports. Thus the evaluation of the performance of the different models will be very valuable to the climate research community.

To have confidence in model predictions of future climate change we need to evaluate whether computer models can simulate altered climates of the past. Our project applies this approach to study tropical climate during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) – the period during the last ice age when ice sheets reached their maximum volume leading to a sea level drop of more than 120 m. In addition, greenhouse concentrations decreased by 100 ppm, leading to global cooling of considerable magnitude. Because of this, the LGM has drawn a great of research attention, as it could be an “opposite” analogue for future greenhouse warming.

Models and theory predict stronger atmospheric convection in response to glacial cooling – the opposite for the global warming case, for which convection is expected to weaken. However, models show large departures from this response over the Indo-Pacific warm pool (IPWP), where large continental shelves, now submerged, where exposed due to the lowered glacial sea level. Using paleoclimate data and model simulations our NSF-funded research showed that these landmasses experienced a more continental, hence dry, climate leading to reduced atmospheric convection that weakened the Walker circulation during the LGM (DiNezio and Tierney 2013).

While there is no future analogue for the response to glacial sea level, we found that the changes in the Walker circulation are amplified by an active Bjerknes feedback in the Indian Ocean. Climate model simulations and paleo observations indicate that during the LGM, the Indian Ocean exhibited a climate state similar to the Pacific, with much colder sea-surface temperatures in the east relative to a less cold west (DiNezio et al. 2016, DiNezio et al. in review). These findings revise the long-standing belief that tropical climate change is dominated by changes in the Pacific and support the emerging view that the Indian Ocean behaves autonomously on multi-decadal and longer timescales, with important implications for regional hydroclimate prediction.

Our NSF-funded research on glacial climates also revealed important new details on monsoon dynamics. Previous studies have argued that monsoon weakening during glacial periods is simply the terrestrial manifestation of global shifts in the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) – a response controlled by a radiative imbalance between the hemispheres. Our results promote an alternative view in which monsoon systems of the Northern hemisphere weaken due to convective inhibition driven by import of cold, dry air generated over the Laurentide ice sheet into the tropics (Bhattacharya et al. 2017, DiNezio et al. in review).

Bhattacharya, T., J. E. Tierney, and P. N. DiNezio, 2017: Glacial reduction of the North American Monsoon via surface cooling and atmospheric ventilation, Geophys. Res. Lett., 44, 5113–5122.
